posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
This board is for the discussion of classic, or "retro" games, including consoles, computer games, arcade games (including pinball) and any other forms of video games. Retro gaming means platforms launched in 2001 and earlier, and official game titles for those platforms released no later than December 2007 (homebrew console games made after this date will be permitted). The Microsoft Xbox, Nintendo GameCube, Nintendo Game Boy Advance, and Sony PlayStation 2 will now be considered "retro".

Helpful links:
Game Tech Wiki
Emulation General Wiki

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
What was your first experience playing Doom?
>late 1994 sunday afternoon
>7yr old me, obsessed with Mortal Kombat 2
>don't read gaming magazines, out of the loop about PC games in general
>dad brings home a big box with cool artwork and floppies inside
>"drop your nintendo, anon, I've got something here"
>"nooo dad, not your simulators again"
>(I actually loved playing F117 with him but all I wanted to play at the moment was Mortal Kombat 2)
>"It's a shooter game like contra but it's in first person like you are watching the action with your own eyes, anon"
>"yeah dad, like in your simulators. This is a really stupid idea"
>dad switches on the PC. I don't like it much because "Super Nintendo has cooler games" and I'm always afraid to break it somehow. I am not allowed to switch it on and use it on my own
>Windows 3.1 starts but dad shuts it down to "free the memory"
>starts a blue-windowed shell instead
>I am looking at the game box while the game installs. It says Doom II
>some of my classmates were joking about Doom when the lights went flickering in the class. Never seen the game myself and never knew that there are two of them
>after the setup process the game is launched, first level starts, I see pic related
>"huh, these stairs look cool"
>dad moves around, shoots
>"definitely cool"
>I ask to try myself and for the rest of the session it's just me playing and dad watching me play and giving advice
>we finish the game a couple of weeks later. Keyboard only, frequently getting scared and lost in the levels, save scumming
>It's the best gaming experience in my life, thanks dad.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>9558129
Fucking horrible game even for 1993 standards. Cannon Fodder and Syndicate left it in the dust that very same year. Hired Guns, while it isn't 3D, offers much, much more variety and customisation and an incredible 4 player co-op gameplay never seen before in an FPS game. Doom was an absolute snoozefest that became boring within a week once the novelty wore off. It had a really huge mass appeal because anyone with more than half a braincell could get into it. The midi music was fucking awful, repetitive, and aggravating. Its a tech demo, not a video game. It's not the CoD of it's era, at least CoD games are actual games with actual challenge and replayability.

posts.name: Anonymous

>>9560597
In order to run Doom full screen at an acceptable speed in 1993, you needed a 486DX-66 PC with 8MB RAM at least. That would cost you around $3000 at the lowest, plus $529 for a CPU accelerator and another $300 for a Sound Blaster. You could easily spend $4500 on a PC just to play Doom.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>9558129
I preordered via phone to ID based on some screenshots in magazines which did not even have any lighting/shading model and the joy I had with Wolfenstein 3D. The game did not look as good to me as the well lit with better status bar betas in those screenshots. I was on a 386DX-40 so performance was bad, practically unplayable without switching to lower res and reducing the screen playable area. I stuck with Wolfenstein 3D for the performance reasons, but still managed to play though on those low settings. Unlike how it seems to be played by all others, perhaps I did not like it as much since I took it more cautiously trying not to waste the resources on the ground (small health at 10 damage, large for 25, and I would save the items that boost over 100% to collect in backtracking after everything was dead). I guess this was the reason I am not as impressed with the genre like others, but that's my odd taste in games yet I still think it is a very good game.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>9553212
It was an extrordinarily massive mistake on SEGA and Suzuki's part. However, it did revolutionize gaming and help launch the career of Toshihiro Nagoshi, whose Yakuza franchise would eventually make serious money for SEGA, so there is that. Suzuki is a moron, but I honestly really love this game.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
I don't blame them for -trying-.

But it's obvious that Dreamcast and Shenmue both share a lot of the same fundamental failings. The Dreamcast was essentially built as a final struggle against Sony's PS1 (and rumored PS2) by making something that was much more advanced, and more expensive. Audiences just didn't click with it, and Sega were left with an expensive failure that quickly got superseded. The same is basically true with Shenmue. Shenmue could've worked if it was a legit system-seller like GTA or Halo, but it wasn't.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com: The realization that Sega could not compete with media giants like sony, microsoft and nintendo on hardware space, and it was the correct call.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com: They needed a killer app to sell the console. Didn't work but it's always a gamble.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>9553232
Audiences definitely clicked with it, the DC was a massive success at first. The truth is that the PS2 was going to sweep the floor with everyone, not even Nintendo could dream to compete with the massive install base of the PS1 and the massive hype surrounding the PS2. And even though both the GC and the Xbox had excellent games and superior hardware, neither stood a chance either way. Even being weaker hardware-wise wasn't even that big of a deal for the DC as consoles in Japan have extraordinarily long life spans, both the Neo Geo AES and the SNES received games well into the late 90s. In fact, Sega could've absolutely kept supporting the DC for its lifespan (even the PS1 received games that the DC never did like THPS3), but they were so used to being a top contender that it would've been too demoralizing.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com: Shenmue was a vanity project, and it rightfully floundered.

It's low stakes to everyone but Ryo. Normal life continues for everyone in town, because nothing tragic happened to them. To them, Iwao's murder was just a news story. It's a believable depiction, and one of the things that makes this game special.

posts.name: Anonymous

>>9553212
It was a gamble that didn't pay off, BUT people put too much emphasis on it making back the budget alone.
A lot of money was spent on tech as well IIRC, and that (as well as experience of making these types of games) was carried over into future projects too.
So yes it looks particularly bad on paper (and in reality was definitely not a success) but there's more to it. Not to mention the idea wasn't to make the money back in one or two games, but to launch a franchise, so they intended to take a loss on the early games in the hope it would be a 'Final Fantasy' series for them. Shame it didn't pan out, Shenmue 1 and 2 were really cool. 3 got some things right, but mostly didn't live up to the previous games.
I think the Dreamcast would have been finished regardless though.

It's not hard to see the comparisons, especially once encounters become much more frequent in Shenmue 2. They are both ostensibly beat em ups with a wide variety of activities to perform in the overworld. Yakuza is much more bound by genre convention as it released later, a more straightforward mashup of beat em up and RPG rather than the vague structure of Shenmue. They have totally different priorities and atmosphere, but there are things in common.

I've never tried it myself, but it seems like this control scheme would probably work just fine if you got used to it. I grew up on NES, so I'm used to attack being on a left face button, and jump being on a right face button. With MMX I added dashing to L, and with MMZ I added secondary weapon to R. With newer games I just added new buttons to what I was already used to from older games. Just because these controls work perfectly fine and feel natural to me after playing action platformers this way for decades, doesn't make it the only good control scheme. If you're a youngster whose first game was Halo, Minecraft, or Souls, it makes sense that you might gravitate towards controls that put your primary actions on shoulder buttons. Putting your primary actions on shoulder buttons is completely unnecessary in a game where you don't need to use the right analog stick to move your camera, but that doesn't mean that it's /wrong/ either. It's just different.

Well there's several categories of turnbased

*SRPG/Tactics game: Start with the wii Fire Emblem

*Civ/Grand Strategy games: Don't know, go ask for starter games on that board

*Dungeon Crawler: Ertrian Oddyssy, one of the later ones, or SMT

*Roguelike: Dragon fangs (not vr)

*Traditional JRPG: Much wider selection of style. FF7 is a good intro the cinematic style as for the more classical style I recommend FF5, just understand FF5 is a shitty game until you beat the first boss and the fun of being able to easily mix and match classes opens up. Snes9x GX is the best that the Wii can do, that much is true, however the compatibility list is already massive and most games you won't notice any issues.

...and a new version has been released last year, 4.5.3:
https://wiibrew.org/wiki/Snes9x_GX

List of changes:
>Compiled with latest devkitPPC/libogc
>Updated to latest Snes9x
>Added "Enable Turbo Mode" toggle to the Video Settings menu (based on InfiniteBlueGX's code)
>Improved forwarder support
>Added ability to use "Original" render mode in 480p configurations (niuus)
>Added new speeds for Super FX overclocking (niuus)
>Added a toggle to hide/show the SRAM save button in the save menu UI (saulfabregwiivc)
>Added Scale2x video filter and rename >Scanlines filter (thanks Tanooki16!)
>Adjusted scanline filter (Thanks Tanooki16!)

TL:DR - you're both right in a sense, chill.

N64 emulation is really not that bad. In fact, it's quite good. Graphical things, mostly. The biggest is to bring over the plant sprites from 94P to update episode 4 to look more appropriate. posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>9554771
There's been a few.
>owner of Color Dreams sees Hellraiser in theaters
>blown the fuck away
>decides that he HAS to make a game out of this somehow
>actually manages to wrangle a license for the Hellraiser IP
>it's gonna be on the NES
>also it's gonna use a special cartridge with an extra processor to make an even more advanced game
>planned sfuff like procedurally generated levels (and maybe demons?)
>some experimenting is done with the prototype cartridge they built, but the realization sets in pretty quickly that this game is going to be quite expensive to produce, meaning it's going to be quite expensive to buy
>also Color Dreams is not licensed by Nintendo so distribution and sales are never easy for them to begin with
>game gets shelved
>some years later (probably 1992 or 1993), they get the itch to try again, and they still have the license
>get the idea to license the Wolfenstein 3D engine from iD Software
>do a bit of work on this as a PC game, but then iD Software starts showing, and eventually releasing, Doom
>a game about demons and hell which would make their effort look incredibly dated and primitive in comparison
>the time for their licensing deal expires soon as well, so they decide "Fuck it." and scrap the game
>famously, Color Dreams rebrands to Wisdom Tree and focus on making Christianity themed games to sell via religious channels (where Nintendo couldn't throw any of their weight around, because they weren't distributing anything themselves around those parts)
>as Wisdom Tree, they make an unlicenses SNES game about Noah's Ark, using the Wolfenstein 3D engine they licensed
>no idea if they got any further technical assistance from iD, but supposedly the guys all thought it was incredibly funny
I don't think any pictures of gameplay or anything ever surfaced of the planned NES game, just a couple of (probably mockup) title screens. Some assets from the PC game were actually released much later on, it looks pretty preliminary.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
There was another game started by another company (Magnetic Interactive or something like that) in 1995, Hellraiser : Virtual Hell. This used the Build Engine, and was supposed to be about advanced virtual reality research accidentally "reaching hell", supposedly it was meant to feature a mix of different kinds of gameplay, as well as going from 1st person to 3rd person, one of the possible bad endings was the player becoming a cenobite.
The concept for the game sounds like it was ambitious (if strangely fourth wall breaking), what few screenshots and shown off assets exist look pretty, and it was to feature some voice acting and FMV footage of Doug Bradley himself as Pinhead, recorded this during downtime from shooting Hellraiser Bloodlines.
The devs could never cope with the engine (be that for having too ambitious of a vision, or if they ran into the kind of problems Blood's devs did trying to get technical support from Ken Silverman), and in spite of having supposedly like +90% of the assets done, they think the game is shitty and unsalvageable, so they cancel it.

A couple of screenshots of empty levels were shown, some map layouts, and apparently some sprites and textures were shown at some point, in .jpeg form. I think this game was much further along, and probably had at least a somewhat playable build.

Here's a good article about this:
https://andrewyoderdesign.blog/2019/08/04/the-door-problem-of-combat-design/
Definitely read it despite what I'm about to say, but you will never fully solve this issue. I just fired up Plutonia's first map, pic related. I have zero reason to venture outside of this hallway. I will likely die if I go out to take on the chaingunners without the safety net of retreating further into the hall. I think you should just do what you feel you need to do if you have some kind of arena in mind. Croteam will just fucking lock doors for no reason and pit you against a horde of Mental's forces and it's great. People get really weird about these things in Doom and Quake maps, and I get it, artifice like that shows the hand of the author, but by and large I really don't give a shit.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>9558721
it's fairly easy but ergonomy is weird, and there's no battle forecast like in more recent games, you'd have to calculate everything manually to know the hit % and damage dealt
I think you weren't meant to overanalyze stats and anticipate how much HP you'll lose from each fight, just do a rough estimate (your units are generally very strong anyway). Inventory management is also annoying but there aren't many weapon types anyway, so it's not like you spend that much time trading items as >>9558706 said.
Similarly, the game has permadeath and I think you were meant to play in "iron man", meaning that if someone dies, you don't restart and just keep playing. The game gives you a ton of units to make up for losses. If you had to restart with each death then the game would become longer and more tedious to complete (of course if Marth dies you simply restart the chapter, don't have the redo the whole game).

So it can seem like a tedious game depending on how you play it, but truth is that you can actually play it like a complete moron, without caring about micromanaging, deaths and stats, and still succeed, as long as you don't throw your weak units in the middle of a big enemy squad or something stupid.
Just make sure you train Marth, he's very strong and you'll kinda need him for the final boss. And pay attention to the dialogue, there's some kind quest you have to do to get access to an important and specific item.
Also, just remember that the game will give you a fuckton of money, you'll always have more than enough, so you don't have to be greedy.

>>9560056
Probably, although the anons saying the C64 is much more susceptible to voltage/power issues nuking the various chips are definitely correct. The original PSUs are literal timebombs. When I picked one up out of a thrift shop back in 2018 I ran it just long enough to confirm it could boot and that the 1541 was functional, and even that was a potential risk. If nothing else with these a modern replacement PSU is essential

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>9560340
In fact a bad PSU will blow up the RAM before it harms any other components in the computer. The RAM chips have small, dense dies and are very easily damaged by overvoltage while the main chips like VIC-II et al have relatively large, coarse dies that can take a fair bit of abuse. So the RAM is basically like a crumple zone in a car frame; it will get toasted first and provide a warning of imminent PSU failure.

If you happen to find a C64 with bad RAM it's more often than not a PSU fault and an indication that you'd better throw that PSU away at once (occasionally you'll come across a machine with Micron RAM chips which do a fine job of self-destructing with no help needed).

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>9558641
A lot of them would be looking at pretty niche audiences because many of them are too hard for most players today (partially because they were designed with the intent of trying to get people to pay out more money to continue playing). You could maybe have a set of 'retro cabinets' with certain sets of controls or features as to allow you to play certain genres of old classic arcade games, and some fightan game ones, I guess essentially MAME cabinets, but these would not have a very strong draw with most audiences today, hell, they were already waning in the late 80s as home gaming kept getting better.

What you need is gaming experiences which aren't easily played at home. Sidescrollers and fighting games with nice graphics are easily available either with ports or rereleases, modern substitutes, or piracy. Instead you need to focus on more advanced experiences, like lightgun shooting games (something which is essentially dead with modern systems), certain kinds of VR gaming, DDR, and then games with special motorized physical cabinets where the player interacts with or is housed in a large prop, like Afterburner or some of those racers.

The only people today who are going to go to an arcade to play the kind of games they can easily play at home are going to be enthusiasts of these things or people with a nostalgia for old ones. Pong caught on because that was something people couldn't get elsewhere, and as home games became a thing and got more advanced, arcades kept developing, they didn't resign themselves to making a prettier Pong, which is more or less how arcades went in the 90s and 2000s.

If it isn't novel, there's no draw.

- CRTs are no longer produced because they have inferior picture quality versus LCDs
- CRTs emit dangerous levels of X-rays or other forms of radiation
- CRTs always have easily-visible flicker
- CRTs always cause eyestrain
- CRTs always make a high-pitched squealing noise
- CRTs contain lethal amounts of electricity, even when unplugged
- CRTs need calibration more than two to three times a year
- Overall CRT black levels are not superior to LCDs because ambient light ruins CRT black levels
- Analog CRTs have more processing time than digital LCDs due to poor RAMDAC performance
- Afterimages caused by phosphor decay are extremely annoying and are a significant downside of CRTs
- Sending an improper mode (resolution or refresh rate) to a CRT can cause permanent damage
- CRTs cannot have touchscreens
- 4:3 is so bad that nobody should use a non-widescreen CRT
- The Sony GDM-FW900 is the only CRT worth owning
- Curved CRTs have objectively inferior picture quality versus flat CRTs with otherwise equal specifications
- CRTs should not be used because they are heavier and deeper than LCDs
- CRTs have severe reflections because they do not have matte coats
- CRTs can be permanently damaged by nearby magnets
- You will not have sex in 2023
- Analog signals limit a CRT's resolutions and refresh rates and negatively effect picture quality
- Heavy metals are used in CRT glass to reduce radiation

> Analog CRTs have more processing time than digital LCDs due to poor RAMDAC performance
perhaps true for graphics cards and monitors, but that is the fault of the graphics card, not the CRT.
an NTSC signal directly drives the electron beam. it don't get no faster than that. video game consoles used a technique called "double strike" to get 240p instead of 480i, essentially sending an invalid NTSC signal to get the beam to draw the same lines instead of alternating. hence those scanny ass scanlines.
> CRTs cannot have touchscreens
they sure as fuck did, and they existed since the early 80s. they were common on ATM machines.
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=ExKowj2g8N8

seriously be careful if you decide to fuck around inside of one.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>9550859
It's functionally identical to an F-type connector that you typically associate with RF input. It's the same signal just shaped differently.

Any RF box will do. Or actually, you don't even need a box; the purpose of that box was so that you could hook up your console without having to give up access to your TV channels. But since analogue TV isn't a thing anymore, it's a moot point. For instance you can just hook a Nintendo or Atari straight into the coax port without a box and it'll work just fine (actually better since less chance of interference from a shitty box)

If you have an s-video port then you don't need a s-video to scart adapter. The problem with those HDMI converters (and anything else that calls itself a converter/scaler) is that you'll have a bit of input lag and also your output will be 480i instead of 240p. posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>9558619
completely normal, especially for the top and bottom. its called overscan. you'll notice most old games don't have status bar information in the very top and bottom of the screen because of this reason.
a little bit is fine and normal: about 8 pixels or one square in any direction. just center it the best you can.
FCEUX by default cuts off the top and bottom 8 pixels of the screen by default, it was assumed TVs just were this way.
WARNING: you don't want to go crazy adjusting it either: if you make it perfect for your NES, your SNES and PlayStation will be out of whack, etc etc. analog signals were never perfect.

i took some pics to compare 16:9 mode anamorphic widescreen vs letterboxing.
i don't have any /vr/ games that do anamorphic widescreen, 240p or 480i, so here's a wiiu setting screen, connected to an sd flat screen tube (it needs some adjustment) that does 16:9 mode. the wiiu is here set to output 480i onto a 4:3 screen, which it automatically letterboxes. the result is that the picture is displayed in 360 horizontal lines.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com: and here's the same screen but with the wiiu set to output 480i anamorphic widescreen, and the tv set to 16:9 mode. this shrinks the vertical deflection so all 480 horizontal lines are used to display the picture. all wiiu examples are over component

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com: here's a close-up of star fox zero's title screen letterboxed. i don't know if the wiiu internally renders at 360 or renders at higher and then downscales.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com: and the same but in 16:9 mode. as for how it looks in person, the flicker is less in 16:9 mode, and the "scanlines" (black spaces) aren't as apparent. interlacing artifacts (because it's one frame per field, not sure what the terminology is) also seem to be less apparent in 16:9 mode, but i don't know why that would be. as far as picture quality goes, the difference didn't seem that big. noticeable only if you're looking for it. i'd say see for yourself if you have the option.

>Conceived and co-designed by Nick Bruty, MDK was Shiny's first PC game, and was notable for using software rendering, requiring a Pentium or equivalent microprocessor, rather than necessitating any GPU enhancements, despite its large 3D levels and complex polygonal enemies. As the developers were attempting very ambitious things, they had to write their own programming language from scratch. Additionally, when in sniper mode, the player has the ability to zoom up to 100x, but the developers chose not to employ any of the standard solutions to pop-up, such as clipping or fogging. They also worked to ensure the game ran at a minimum of 30fps at all times on all machines. The game's original system requirements were a 60 MHz Pentium, 16MB of RAM, 17MB of hard drive storage, an SVGA compatible video card, and a Sound Blaster or equivalent sound card.

>>9551524
Having played and finishing both the PSX and the PSP versions, I'd say PSX with a few mods.

First of all, grab Final Fantasy Tactics: The Lion War and apply it to the base game:
https://ffhacktics.com/smf/index.php?topic=12767.0

This adds all of the stuff from the PSP release into the PSX version, save for:
1. An additional character Luso (he's from Final Fantasy Tactics A2 on the DS, but lore-wise doesn't make any sense for him to be in the game anyway) who got replaced by Ashley Riot from Vagrant Story (another game set in the Ivalice region, also on PSX, in terms of the setting this is the latest entry timeline-wise) - but he's been done really tastefully.
2. One character class (Onion Knight), which kinda sucked anyway and was a major pain in the ass to master.
3. The updated translation, it sticks to the straight to the point, no bullshit script of the PSX release as opposed to going all Shakespearean on your ass. Some people will love it, others will hate it - there's two crowds of FFT fans, plenty of arguments have been made for both translations over the years.

So that's what you'd miss out on. But holy fuck do you get so much more, with Continue+ and NG+ options, three additional endgame characters you can recruit (demons) after you've finished the game for the first time, additional skills, being able to change the difficulty, stat resetting option once you've reached level 99 with a character (won't take long, trust) and would like to improve your builds, fuckloads of quality of life little patches etc. Can't go back to the vanilla FFT after this, PSX or PSP, this mod rocks

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>9551524
PS1 version modded with the extra stuff the PSP version added is the best of both worlds. The reason to not use the PSP version itself is because the translation was shit and done by someone who did not understand Matsuno's writing. The original game's very blunt, matter-of-fact way of talking is in fact how the characters talk in Japanese, they don't act like they're in a stage production. Also it ran like absolute shit on an actual psp and it took like a decade for PPSSPP to come into existence, so the only way you could get it running well was by playing a modded ISO which is a non-issue now but you can just play the PS1 version.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>9552687
...once you get your PSX FFT disc image patched with The Lion War, I'd also recommend downloading a patch that replaces the PSX movie clips with the anime-like ones from the PSP release:
https://ffhacktics.com/smf/index.php?topic=12945.0

Also makes the transition from the intro sequence to the start menu much smoother. So overall deffo grab it.

And then there's another patch you could consider, which adds further quality of life fixes to the game, but this one's a bit of a bitch because it could potentially introduce some bugs that weren't present in The Lion War mod originally:
https://ffhacktics.com/smf/index.php?topic=12769.0

As an example, I've had one fight constantly crashing the game in DuckStation (emulator I'm using) no matter what. I reloaded the save file before the battle using an ISO with just The Lion War mod + movie patch, finished it no problems, saved and then continued playing with the ISO that also has them QoL fixed without further crashes, but because of this I'm not sure whether I should recommend it.

As an example it allows you to send special characters (like Cloud, who someone mentioned already) on missions/errands and boost their skills that way, which is a mad fast way of going about it without grinding for hours - normally that's something you could only do with "generic" characters. And that's great, that's the real juicy bit here really, but again, not nearly as heavily tested as The Lion War and there could be bugs, full disclosure.

If you'll have trouble patching, I can upload the disc image for you in a few hours probably, but you'd have to link me to some sort of a free file uploading platform because honestly I've no clue what the fuck people use nowadays.

>>9554775
Now for some extreme cope and education about an iconic line which was altered heavily in the PSP Translation.
They changed the layout of the scene for the PSP version entirely.
Originally Delita delivers the iconic line as he looks back towards Agrias who was trying to stop him. The PSP version has him direct the line towards the princess herself since Agrias wasn't even in the same vicinity as him until shortly after the line was spoken.
https://youtu.be/ghYPElytjpY?t=13
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=DpQX9vxjjIM
Therefore, there was a significant change in this line's intent between versions which, in my opinion, causes the more curt "blame yourself or god" to seem much more convincing than if he'd said the more flowery line to Agrias before running off.
The opposite holds true for the PSP version, where it seems to make considerably more sense for him to say "Tis your birth and faith that wrong you, not I."
tl;dr neither version is incorrect, and it's entirely down to the precise context of the given version of the game.

And the bad Conan the Barbarian game, that too.

from the wiki on it:

"Conan is an action game developed by Eastridge Technology and published by Mindscape. The game is actually a conversion of the computer game Myth: History in the Making for the Commodore 64. The game has also been mislabeled with the subtitle The Mysteries of Time, but this title does not exist neither in the game nor the manual. In this game, you play as the titular hero Conan, who must go through seven levels and brave the challenges of each level. There is also a bit of puzzle-solving required to get through each level, like acquiring a trident to kill the boss of the first level with, in which you must cut down a hanging skeleton, which triggers a demon holding the trident to appear.

The game was negatively received by critics due to its poor gameplay and graphics. The game was single-handedly programmed by Nick Eastridge, but the game was rushed in development by Mindscape, who forced Eastridge to complete the game quickly."

TLDR; it was rushed and was a conversion of a history game so the final boss is a pharoah monster.

>>9544364

Honestly I'm more impressed by someone being a video game programmer back in the day, even if they were shit at it, because it was a new field and not at all prestigious or lucrative.
People were coding stuff in their spare time at home and mostly dealing with how to implement ideas they randomly had or trying to reverse-engineer games they liked. Nothing was done for fame or virtue signaling.

I remember my dad used to buy these ZX81/Spectrum magazines that had entire pages of code in them. You would literally transcribe the code from the magazine and you got a playable game out of it.
Point being that there was a love and pursuit of discovery there and the entire gaming field was uncharted waters. Real pioneers.

posts.com:
I just finished the illusion of gaia, and while it was a enjoyable game, why did it feel so shittily made? I've heard this trilogy get wanked hard an while soul blazer was an amazing game, IoG just felt odd. There was very little cohesion between story and gameplay. And even in the gameplay, which was decent there were blatant errors. Such as one of the dark power abilities being completely useless (I'm referring to Freedian's earthquake, which can only be used when jumping down and stuns enemies for a long time. But after you unlock his ability, every opportunity to use this ability you are faced with an enemy which is intially invulnerable, which means you have to wait until the stun finally releases before you can even attack him. Completely useless)
I wonder whether there were some sort of production issues, because this is only one of the many blatant errors in this game, which definitly makes it worse than Soul blazer. Haven't played terranigma yet. Opinions on Illusion of gaia?

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
It's the weakest of the main 4. (ActRaiser, Blader, Gaia, Tenchi Souzou)

Still has a lot of striking audiovisual moments for '93. But I agree that it's an uneven game.

Keep in mind that these games were made in quick succession unlike anything that happens today. They made:

ActRaiser
Soul Blazer
ActRaiser 2
Illusion of Gaia
Robotrek
Terranigma

All in the span of 5 years. The glut around '93 was overkill and bled into production deadlines/budget. ActRaiser 2 was likely not a planned game but asked for by Enix USA (and to remove the SIM elements) because it had been a hit in the West.

>>9554370
It's why I love it, and why it's my favorite Quintet game. I really love Illusion of Gaia and it's the one game I really wish there was a retranslation of, as I feel like something was lost in it.
Quintet managed to pull off a very specific mood that almost no other company ever did. A certain somberness, a game focused on harsh realities in some specific way.

Finding the wild animals in the zoo, and the goat eating her dead husband in Terranigma also are like this. The Inca Ship of Gold in IoG is a good one too. The animal kingdom in Soul Blazer. The invention of music to mourn their dead in ActRaiser.

br here.
the whole "omg master system is still popular in Brazil!" is actually a meme. Yes we do have a manufacturer called tectoy who has the license for sega stuff and yes they kept making master systems (as well as mega drive), but master system was never as popular as memes made you believe it was. In actual times when it could have been popular it was vastly overshadowed by famiclones (which can't be calculated in quantities sold for obvious pirate reasons, but believe me, for every kid who had a master, 50 had a famiclone).
Master system was mostly the low cost sega console aunts and grandmas would get when kids asked for "the Sega" (meaning the mega drive, which is what kids wanted in the 90s, not the Master)
By the late 90s/early 00s, chipped playstations were super affordable thanks to very cheap bootleg games, and K62 computers let everyone play games on PC for cheap also thanks to piracy (and cyber cafes with LAN)
Master system was never a real mvp as people were made to believe. Sorry for breaking the illusion of brazil being magical master system land.

>>9555159
It's possible to force your switch to use the 1.0.0 version of Atari 50 that has Warbirds still in it. The issue is, you need to do a factory reset on your switch. As long as you've let a physical game update, you can't run that game ever in the future without having at least that update. There's some sort of data that remains after you delete data that tells the switch you NEED to update before you can play. Factory reset is the only way to clear that data. Factory reset your switch, then take it offline and put the cartridge in and install the game and disable auto-updates for that game, then your switch should have Atari 50 with Warbirds and can be safely taken back online.
I know your anger, I felt it the day I brought home a PS2 and MGS3 Substance and was all excited to play Metal Gear Online, only to find out they shut the servers down a few months prior.

>>9556962
>This could effect all games on all consoles btw. What's to stop them from sending updates like this to all other collections or standalones? The future looks grim.

It's actually much worse than that. When it becomes sufficiently practical, and eventually it will, mainstream single-player games will not only be online-only but streaming-only. The general public will embrace the convenience of paying a subscription to access all the games in a provider's library, without having to worry about disk space, let alone shelf space. This all-you-can-play model will take the edge off how they don't actually *own* anything in that library, whose contents are subject to change without notice.

There will be nothing for us to back up, unpatch, crack, pirate, or preserve, because all the code and assets will be out of reach on some corporate cloud server. You will have no recourse when they change a game, retire it, or revoke your access for whatever reason.

No matter how digitally locked down they are, movies, music, and ebooks can at least be recorded through the analog hole (i.e. filming the screen), but games will be at the absolute mercy of rightsholders.

t. Cassandra

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>9560002
The Lynx has a custom 16 bit 16Mhz CMOS handling the sprites and rendering the graphics, and a 4Mhz 65C02 (clocked faster than the SNES CPU) handling the general game logic. It also has a dedicated math ASIC that could transform the sprites quickly or something like that. Not even the SNES or Genesis could match the Lynx's performance, let alone the 7800. It's a low res amiga on steroids.

It's a latin prefix originally. It means "from before". posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
Almost one week with the RG351v (ARKos). Thoughts so far:

- Battery reading is pretty inaccurate. Sometimes you turn it off, turn it on and the next time the percentage is a 1% higher

- Battery + built in wifi = bad: If you are going to download thumbnails / boxart or update cores / assets, do it while connected to the DC and disable wifi immediately after. It sucked a 30% just doing that.

- Gaming experience: Surprised to see it can do CPS3 with not a lot of hiccups. GBA paired with the LCD3X shader mitigates well enough the scaling artifacts when not using integer scaling. 240p PSX games like Klonoa are the ones that benefit the most from the small screen. Snes and Nes are as annoying as ever with the non square pixels if you have bad OCPD about stretching artifacts, as usual.

- Comfort: The d-pad is placed higher than on the og gameboy, so the corner gets into the soft of the hand and hurts a bit until you learn to adapt the posture. The analog stick placement justifies why I did not want the model with two of them. For Ridge Racer Type 4 I just place the left hand lower to not feel it too much. If I really wanted to play an analog only game, I would end using the Gamesir X2 instead.

- Commuting and travelling: Beats lugging around a Nintendo Switch for a quickie in the train. Easier to store. Loses points for not having bluetooth. I can do without wifi, but headphone cables are always a risk

- Did I really need this: Sure, it's cool to be able to play MVS Meta Slug X on the go, but then I ask myself why would I want to play on a "tiny screen" when I can do it on a 40" tv and see all the details. It's great as a replacement for aging handheld consoles, but for TV out consoles it may be better to get one of the other handhelds with bigger screens

That's it for now, I guess. Decent hardware, Need to find a pouch for it. the grey color, rather than the old GB, reminds me more of the Watara Supervisision.

>random knock off device
No. It’s the gp2x the successor to the gp32 the first handheld emulation machine ever made, shit for brains. Both of these consoles were huge in the home brew scene and sparked the handheld emulation scene we have today. I’m dead serious. Gamepark split up after making the gp32, which caused the gp2x to be made, but the teams were competing with each other which eventually led to the pyra and the gpd win to be the competitors. That was the beginning of the hand held computer and handheld emulation machine fad that we see now. It all stems from the massive home brew scene on the gp32 and gp2x. It doesn’t get you very far being a dumb faggot, but now you know.

- weird dual stick placement
- can install Android and all the associated benefits and games

I think it's just "more" than RR1 and RR:R. As good as the arcade ports are, they are just that: arcade games meant for short bursts. Rage was the first entry that had real progression that you could put hours into. Type 4 is better in almost every way but it's a bit too easy where Rage is more of a challenge for longer.
But apart from the jank you mentioned, I found the game to require "perfection" too much. Like because of the constant hills it was all too easy to slightly nudge an AI car which drops you to 60% of your speed and since you're on a hill it's 0 acceleration all the way to the top, losing you so much time.
I think it was the speed ring that killed it for me. LOOONG race and a single mistake meant 3rd place.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>9559083
>Type 4 is better in almost every way but it's a bit too easy
Since we're at it, you can use this code for harder AI:

300AD6D8 0003

This is the rival AI the game uses when you play as Solvalou, which is faster and more aggressive. Obviously, difficulty stays the same if you pick Solvalou, and with PRC it's not much harder, but with DRT and Mappy it's a good challenge.

Also another thing I've discovered: if you play these via emulator, configuring the controller as a NeGcon will give you extra cornering range. Will make the games easier overall, as you can tackle corners more aggressively without the need of drifting, but you might enjoy the extra range. Remember to configure the in-game settings to match your preferences in regards of sensibility and dead zones.

>>9560673

I see three things happening here: decensoring, correction of weirdly shortened scientific creature names, and general rewording that might possibly improve the quality of dialogue and narration. The first is just about irrelevant I think since the censorship seems to have been very small. The second is nice but unnecessary; it's not like you're playing this to study for your paleozoology exam, and there's a certain charm in the weirdly garbled official translations of the names. The third could be good or bad - I don't remember the story ever being hard to understand or anything, but a better translation would still be... better, right? I dunno. You could take the patches or leave them; they sound decent but nonessential. I haven't tried them though.

>>9558707
I had the same pack. My dad bought it for $9.99 at walmart. Torment certainly did get a lot more play. But I enjoyed le vibe sovl of Soulbringer too. Everything seemed a little more real in that game whereas torment is like taking a hallucinogen that straight up transfers you to strange dimension. Soulbringer has this down to Earth euro setting that made its magic feel more special, and the rate at which I would die in meaningless battles made the stakes seem very high. I t was one of those games where I was relieved any time i saw an item.

Also it might be an early progenitor of the glowing pixel search thing. Torment could be said to be worse bc you have to hover mouse-over to see any item/interaction prompts, many of which are hidden under scenery. By contrast I was very happy to have glowing pixel item/interation mode in Soulbringer, as opposed to how that same system feels in super detailed hd++ modern games.

posts.name: Anonymous

>>9525435
A few years ago I was watching random Game Center episodes, my parents and my brother were out of town so I went to my brother's bedroom intent on smoking some of his weed (I had smoked before). He had some sort of dust in a grinder thing (I have no clue about weed stuff other than just smoking it very occasionally).
I put some weed in the pipe with the dust and smoked, waited half an hour and nothing happened, figured I'd smoked too little and just left it at that, then went to take a shower. I was in the shower for a good half an hour before I realized I was finally high. All the lights hurt, and directly looking at one for a brief moment made my ears feel like I was getting hit with cymbals in the head. All I could do was fall on my bed, cover my face with a pillow and focus on Arino's voice until I felt well enough to get up and turn off the lights. GCCX stood there running with me all night, keeping me safe from my druggie demons.
Thank you Arino-san.

>>9559434
If it was just you getting gud and beating the retro-style games included, it wouldn't be so bad. Unfortunately, most of the challenges you need to beat are arbitrary conditions, like "Do a turbo-boost twice during a race" or "Shoot these specific enemies to trigger a warp". So instead of sitting down and getting into the games, you just play with the goal of doing the current challenge. Then once the challenges for that game have been beaten, you move onto the next game. You can keep playing the games, but there is no point since you aren't actually asked to beat them or take the #1 high score.
The games try to capture the "game challenge" feel of the show without understanding that these sorts of games are a lot more fun when you get deep into them and go for the ending instead of just trying to get to the 4th level and do some gimmick trick. Far better suited as a "I need something to keep me busy for 5-10 minutes while I wait" mini-game collection than an actual game you'd want to play for more than 20-30 minutes.
At least, that was my experience playing about halfway through the first two. They might change towards the end, I couldn't be assed to continue.

>>9552965
>Not sure what your priorities are, though

Mostly challenging "footsies". My favorite thing in Castlevania tends to be nailing those high commitment whips and jumps against relatively dynamic and unpredictable baddies.

Second most important being just good platforming making use of those tense high commitment jumps.

Castlevania 4 is generally just a bit too easy. Feels like the stages weren't really designed around the 8 way whipping and changeable jump arcs, since there's so many times where you can easily whip enemies from the floor below or before they can even attack you, and the platforming rarely puts too much pressure on you.

Hell I remember picking it up for the first time in ten years (with almost no memory of any of the stage layouts and bosses) and making it up to the final boss rush without a game over. That's kind of how pushover the game is. Combine that with how loooooooong it is and it can start to feel kind of monotonous in a single sitting playthrough despite how nice the art and music is.

I don't hate it but I like it mostly for the atmosphere and nostalgia. I think I'd put it below 1, 3 ,Bloodlines, x68, and Rondo in terms of level design and mechanics.

>>9553045
>Hagane

The fuck are you talking about.

Hagane is easy as shit comapred to almost every Castlevania outside of 4 and Rondo. I'ts a great game but it's not comparable to Castlevania at all since it's much less methodical and has a much more acrobatic moveset, you can attack while moving, etc. it's an entirely different style of gameplay.

>You just described old games

No. Castlevania has a particular style and particular style of challenges. It's not better or worse, it's it's own thing which has its own particular pleasures.

If you don't like buying your jumps and attacks a wedding ring, they're not for you. But if you do it's a blast. Personally I love 'em all (except Dracula XX)

> it's the only one where I need pixel perfect jumps to a point

I don't remember almost any jumps that felt pixel perfect, though there are certainly some jumps like that in Castlevania 3.

What makes action-platforming hard (in a fun way) isn't pixel perfect or strictly timed jumps anyway. It's putting interesting pressure and challenges and multitasking on you while your platforming. CV4 doesn't really do that.

Anyway I'm not going to get into a pixel by pixel autism level design comparison but running through the entire series almost fresh, all of them gave me satisfying challenges except 4 (and Rondo, but Rondo it was less of a big deal because it's shorter and had more fun stuff going on).

To give one example, not NInja Gaiden got worse when they nerfed the the vertical hitbox on your jumping sword swing in 2. This made hitting enemies while landing much more finnicky and annoying, and thus slowed the pace of the game.

3 kind of addressed this by adding a poweru p that increased your sword range, which was a nice compromise. It also made the jump floatier.

I think I consider the controls in 1 and 3 both superior to 2, but 1 and 3 are both "different" and enjoyable in their own ways.

>You said Hagane

I've 1cc'd a lot of shmups and old games over time. I only really recorded or uploaded the ones I considered particularly challenging. Hagane I thought was an easier clear and took me very little time to do, so I didn't bother recording it.

I don't know why you think that one is a crown jewel of difficulty, I've never heard anyone hold that up on retro forums as particularly challenging. I guess the second loop where everything has super extra HP is harder

>No it's not and 99% of people agree, which is why games evolved the way they did

Even if it were true that consensus means better, that's really not true. There are tons of enduring franchises (including modern, still running ones) that are built around strategic limitations.

Dark Souls for example is pretty much just OG Classicvania combat in 3d. You have non-cancellable attack animations that are not instant and can't be moved during, mobility options which are very limited and set your trajectory in stone for a very specific location, etc.

Or then there's the enduring popularity of many horror games and action-horror games built around strategically limited controls. Resident Evil 2 Remake may have done away with tank controls, but it still put harsh limitations on players movement and dodging options and it was applauded for it. The same could be said of Dead Space 1 and 2 which are absurdly popular and are more or less based on the same very rigid control limitations of RE4-5 and Remake 2, just applied to a more high adrenaline action game.

Making it so you can move and attack at the same time or change the trajectory of mobility moves isn't better or worse (or even more popular are less). It's a design decision that enforces different styles of play.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>9553073
>cant kill Shaft
Grab the Bible from the breakable wall before the boss rush, it makes every boss easier but especially Shaft because you can use it to knock away his fireballs. For the lightning orbs, admittedly that's kind of a crapshoot but if they start drifting away from each other you want to be between them, towards each other you need to backflip away from both of them ASAP. For his third attack, try to backflip over the orbs when they come towards you. It's tough but doable.

As for Dracula phase 1, grab the cross at the start of the level. Whenever Dracula shows up, toss a cross at his face and then backflip over his fireballs. It might take some time to get a good feel for how far from him you have to be, but once you get the timing down he's completely toothless. Also, he'll do the magma ball attack on his 4th teleport first, then on every 5th teleport after that.

>>9532823
There are several good ports. My personal favorite way to play is the M2 3D one on the 3ds. They did a phenomenal job and even fish in a given school are at different depths. I have played it emulated many times though with no issue.

I do recommend a guide if you feel stuck, there are two quests near the beginning where you rescue lost dolphins and those give you very useful abilities for the rest of the game.

Finally though, if you find yourself very stuck or the game is too hard, or you just want to play it more casually, all versions including the GBA port have the debug code which is quite robust.

You can yourself invulnerable if you want, level select or teleport to any area of the current zone. Almost more fun though is you can change the music tempo which given Ecco's incredible soundtrack makes for some really cool variations you can do.

>>9532972
Good luck with it, I'm glad to help! It's one of my favorite games of all time, but I understand well why it's always been a little niche. My suggestion if you try again is just take it slow for a while and learn how the game flows. The second level has an octopus that is there to help teach you. You'll feel low on air and like you should be rushing, but the octopus will slap you back of you do. In Ecco, rushing is what usually kills you. Your air is always depleting and you will think you're going to drown if you don't, but success relies on keeping calm under pressure and being accurate. Many people say it's crazy hard, but really outside of the Asterite fight and the Vortex queen at the end, it's really not that difficult ot just takes a kind of mentality that most games don't require as much.

>>9535508
I actually saw it from a totally different perspective, to me it was like "hmmmm never seen this kinda stuff before.."
lets not forget that most of the "sister games" back then were just Barbie crap. back then a Dolphin on the cover did not automatically give people the feeling of it being a kids game, hell the Genesis was even marketed as a console for dudebros way before the xbox360 coined that phrase.
back then most of us just didn't even feel like we could be subjected to kids games on the Genesis, Snes for sure cuz Nintendo. but Genesis just felt differently.
you saw Toejam & Earl and you didn't think "oh kiddy alien game" no you thought "wow, thats a whacky bro experience!"

Even now when I go through my rom collection and find stuff like Richard Scarry's Busytown it feels.. off somehow. as in "this shouldn't be on the Genesis"
That's just how it was marketed, even Lion King and Aladdin didn't feel like they were for kids, they were for all ages.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>9535820
>It's not something like Space Harrier or Streets of Rage that you can play and even if it kicks your ass, still have fun with the pacing

See I guess I just don't see it that way. While I love Space Harrier to a huge degree, I also like Ecco. They are very different, but I don't see that as a bad thing. I hate this comparison being thrown around, but in many ways Ecco is like Demon's Souls was compared to other contemporary games.

From an objective standpoint there are many harder retro games, Ninja Gaiden, Castlevania 3, Super Ghouls n Ghosts, Battletoads, 1ccing Gradius etc (all of which get regular threads here by people declaring that the difficulty is overstated) are all much harder than anything Ecco throws at you, even the last levels. Most games, especially platformers have similar enough controls that you tangentially get good at others while playing it. With Ecco, nothing else plays like it so you're also learning a whole new control scheme.

However, all those games have a similar flow which is much more action focused. Ecco is all about being careful, scoping out the environment with your sonar and clearing an area of enemies so when you have to rush through you can. It's very different from many other console games of the era, but I don't see that as a bad thing.

>>9536263
It's really not a handwave, it's how the game is designed. You can call it tedious, but it was never meant to be a bing bing wahoo rush to the finish type game. Unreliable just makes no sense, if you want to permakill an enemy, you can. It's about making the decision you want to.

Again as I always say in these threads, since first playing Ecco has always been in my top selection of games and I almost always have a playthrough on the go somewhere. Along with that love is the understanding it doesn't appeal to everyone, but I don't see that as a bad thing. Games should appeal to many different people.

My only sad point is Tides of Time is much more forgotten and has fewer ports. But anyone now who plays a version of the first game and loves it can find a way to play Tides without too much trouble.

I don't think you could reboot the game in this era and have it he the same kind of game. Players now would expect a lot more bells and whistles, Ecco would need branching skill trees, grind xp off jellyfish and items to collect and the like. All that would change what the game is which would be a huge disappointment. One of the very things that makes Ecco so great is how unique it is in many ways and presents a very different kind of game and challenge.

>>9555163
Ohh yes, which is why I say that. I think it wraps up beautifully. Ecco finally defeats the vortex for good, forcing them to co-evolve with life on earth, both giving us insects and making it kinda cool that all those damn crabs you've been killing the whole time.

Then having done his work saving the world, in true hero fashion goes on his way. To me, if someone is looking for that third Ecco game, we got it with Defender of the Future. Ecco disappears into the time steam and then re-emerges in literally a different dimension for a whole new adventure.

posts.com: hats off for trying but it was clearly not ready, neither the engine nor the console. Funny to think that as a 3D remake of Hydlide it's not horrible, but it's also incredibly off the mark. Immercenary on 3DO achieves the 3D open world action game much better, and then obviously everyone does that now in the modern games, but because the hardware and programming tricks have caught up to it. Virtual Hydlide in its time of release would have maybe been okay on 3DO or even PSX with more compromises, or would have probably run acceptably well on 64, but on Saturn it was just too much. It's unfortunate that T&E had such bad luck choosing platforms to work on in the 90's.

Just beat HL1 for the first time. Great impression, the golden standard of what I enjoy in a FPS, don't know how could I have slept on the game for so long. The only thing I expected a bit more was in the story department, and just because I read people praising it.

It got me thinking how different modern and retro games are. >How does HL2 stack against 1?
It's been a while since I played either game, but I remember liking them both a lot. They do very different things, however.
HL2 is definitely much more... setpiecey? than the first game. That isn't to say that the level design is bad, it's just much more linear from how I remember Half-Life's being. I don't really remember the level design being very conducive to doing a lot of exploration.
I really liked all of the weapons in HL2 though, really dug the art design, and since I played it when it was still relatively new (when the Orange Box released) I was also really into the in-engine cutscenes. I liked Episode 1 and 2 a lot, too.
The story isn't going to knock you off your feet and some of the physics "puzzles" might make you roll your eyes, but I think the game is a must-play if you already played Half-Life.

>What are the best standalone/sp mods?
I wish I had an answer for this, but the only mods I ever played were multiplayer. Had shitloads of fun with Zombie Panic and Age of Chivalry back then.

For HL1? My personal picks would be:

Sweet Half-Life
Poke646 + It's sequel Vendetta
Azure Sheep
Point of View (AS and POV cross over with each other's main characters and are connected as mods)
They Hunger
Visitors

Afraid of Monsters Director's Cut
Cry of Fear

Echoes

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>9560581
The upcoming Persona 3 Portable Steam port is going to be very noob friendly, just pay $20 and you're good to go, no need to mod anything or fuck with emulation settings.

The advantages of P3P over FES are full party control out of the box (no need for a mod) and a female MC route with all new social links. But you'll lose out on the 3D overworld, all 3D cutscenes AND all anime (FMV style) cutscenes. See the webm for a quick comparison. Even the dungeon crawling parts that are still 3D will have lower poly models compared to FES. And you also lose out on the post-game story expansion, The Answer (which is similar to the third semester in P4G and P5R).

So, if you're not tech illiterate, playing FES emulated AND modded can be a much better experience. Mods wise I'd recommend:
- full party control + no fatigue*
https://pastebin.com/xjnhHL5e
(just save the pnach file to the PCSX2's cheat folder)
- widescreen fixes
https://gamebanana.com/mods/33852
https://gamebanana.com/mods/33843
- undub if you're a weeb, as the PS2 versions of both P3 and P4 are EN VA only, although I personally find the EN voices more charming
https://gamebanana.com/mods/292547
https://gamebanana.com/mods/413136

*fatigue is a fucking annoying mechanic unique to Persona 3 where party members get "tired" after dungeon crawling for a bit and this will even affect their real world availability for the next few days, I prefer just patching it the fuck out, but you do you, just delete the lines in the pnach file if you think it's cheating

>This is a fine game

- Deadly pits every 2 meters one from another in most stages. Good luck if you are not good with jumps in 3D videogames, because you are going to die every 20 seconds. And hope you have a lot of patience too.

- A lot of mazes in most stages. By the way, in one of them one enemy is heavier and taller than you yet he runsa lot faster than you and if he attacks you, you are pretty dead already.

- Very few enemy variety. No killer dolls, no alura une, no azaghal, no malachi, etc.

- In many stages most rooms looks the same. Its easy to get lost.

- The items in the "shop" are very expensive, and the one who sells them is a ungrateful bastatd if you buy too much items.

Even super castlevania 4, being older, is a lot better than castlevania 64.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.sub: Another World / Out of This World
posts.com:
How did a single frenchman in the late 80s do it? It's all ridiculously slick for its time. There's some really impressive shit here:

>animations and visual style that have aged surprisingly well
>not a word of dialog or spec of UI and yet everything the player needs to know is effortlessly communicated with environmental cues
>incredible pacing (this game makes a compelling argument for why action games should be 2 hours of perfectly paced, varied setpieces rather than bloated and repetitive 10+ hour slogs)
>camera angles and framing decades ahead of the curve
>bespoke ingame setpieces like Buddy's fake surrender or, my personal favorite, kicking a guard in the balls and running to your weapon to quickly shoot him

Fuck, it's so good. I don't think anything released afterward matches this game's level of execution until maybe Half Life 2?

posts.com:
>>9558506
Well finding out what the good ones are is not hard. Racketboy is a good website and youtube has good "hidden gems" "essentials" list for just about every format. If it looks like it's made by a passionate gamer its going to be a good list. If it looks like it's click farm its going to be questionable. You can find 90% of the good games on a given format very easily this way.

As for the reasons why. Well that's a tall order. Most of the reviews written in the past were really just trying to give you enough info so you could decide if you wanted to buy it while pointing out some obvious issues in hopes the dev would read them.

Take that tiny pool of players who are experts in the genre: they can play them at a high level and have played them all. Ok, well among that group you need someone who has the second talent of being very good at introspection, why he likes one more then another, and he needs enough communication skill to be able to put it in writing in the way the rest of us will get it.

Yes those types of reviews exist but they are scattered.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>9558489
>Like what made certain side scrollers good compared to the bad ones
Aesthetics and difficulty. Streets of Rage 2 had fantastic sound design (not just the music) and a few different difficulty levels, none of which were made bullshit just to suck quarters out of you because it was designed as a console game. Most belt scrollers suck because they're all about finding that one thing you do to beat every enemy and finding the One Weird Trick you use to beat each boss. The problem is that none of these tricks were ever intended so they're almost never fun. In the original Final Fight you beat most stuff by doing a little jab infinite, and the original Streets of Rage is basically the same thing. 2 actually gave you a bunch of different options for dealing with normal enemies, different grabs you could do, its weird vaulting mechanic they expanded on for 2, and for the most part they toned down jabs on higher difficulties.

Street Fighter 2 got a bunch of different versions because World Warriors was a glitchy mess released with 4 characters you could fight against but not play as. They had a lot to expand on so they did.

What I struggle with the most is how Ariel/King Triton controls, as it feels like the water is pushing them constantly, it doesn't feel responsive or fluid whatsoever, regardless of how it might be realistic in a way, I also feel the hit boxes needed some work, Ariel/King Triton's attack needed to be more effective, and they desperately needed more invincibility frames... the 1st and especially the 3rd level are both fun, and the reason I go back to this sometimes, the problem is in the 2nd and 4 level, which can both be a chore due to the shortcomings I've mentioned here.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com: Yu-Gi-Oh! Duel Monsters (GB/1998) is one of my favorite video games of all time, and one that I've played more than anybody ever should considering how little depth it actually has, and how ludicrous some decisions by Konami regarding its design were. A few things got me into this, the 1st is that an English translation came out in the last few years and gave me a chance to finally play it, this was the most crucial reason by far, because otherwise I'd have never even attempted to play it, the other reason is that this is historic for the Yu-Gi-Oh! OCG and TCG, since it essentially gave Konami the license for it and was used as the basis for the original rulesets. A lot of things about it are ridiculous, for example, do you want to get a Blue-Eyes White Dragon? Simple, just beat Kaiba... a 100 times, do you want a Red-Eyes B. Dragon? Simple, just beat Joey... a 100 times. You do get a card every 10 wins for each duelist, but the best ones require 100 wins... and I did it for about 5 or 6 of them, to get the cards I wanted, why? Well, this is the closest that we'll ever get to a Duelist Kingdom RPG, and it was my favorite arc, so its won me over for that reason alone, and kept me playing. Also, the artwork is incredible for the hardware and resolution.

Maybe I just don't like this era of FE, IDK.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>9558843
The Master System game came first, then the Genesis game, then Lost Stars (which also had a Master System or Game Gear port, one of the two).
The first Alex Kidd game was about a tyrant named Janken that was taking over Radaxian and Alex having to stop him. It's not a very creative story, but it does have some fluff to it compared to other platformers at the time, like Alex actually being the Prince of Radaxian (something he didn't know until his master told him) or how there's a level after the final boss to tie up a loose end. There's even a minor extended universe component as Igul, Alex's brother and Radaxian's known prince, is actually the protagonist of a game called "Pit Pot" that the producer made prior to making Alex Kidd.
Enchanted Castle follows up on the cliffhanger ending of the first game (Alex's family is mostly saved, but the king is missing he went on vacation and is totally fine) and doesn't make any pretense of having an actual plot like Miracle World did. Lost Stars goes full "Sonic", having a somewhat intricate storyline in the manual/other materials, but zero context in the game itself.

>>9555378
That's entirely on Nintendo of America.

By the time Super Bomberman 3 released in Japan, Hudson Soft USA was closed and had to cancel localizations for Super Bonk 2 and Elfaria (possibly in collaboration with Working Designs, but Hudson would still publish)

Nintendo chose to pick up Super Bomberman 3 and Nintendo of America staff worked on the localization and game testing (there's even footage in a Japanese documentary) much like with Terranigma, they just chose to release it only in Europe.

It's not too weird, because NoE was still a subsidary of NoA and translators were really discouraged from learning Japanese directly (not that it kept them from doing it anyways, and the Japanese staff from appreciating it, and for them to eventually get their autonomy to reduce the +1 year release schedule gaps), but Nintendo of America's weird insistence on killing the SNES as soon as 1995 was something. Metal Warriors by LucasArts was supposed to be a Nintendo-published game too, and they planned an English localization of DBZ Super Butoden 2 (simply called Dragon Ball) in 1996 meant for Mexican audiences.

>>9555689
Scandinavia has its own Nintendo distribution. When Nintendo was busy getting fucked over by Atari (failed 1983 American Famicom launch as rebranded Atari, Atari intended to bury Nintendo alive by sitting on the rights all along, Nintendo headhunted some of those Atari marketing teams and tried to slowly piece together its own distribution) and Mattel/Bandai (European distribution until 1993), the Scandinavian branch was the only one actually doing its job, and even getting titles sooner than other regions.

>>9555732
Sony SCEA rejects 2D game > publisher tries to release it in Europe, if the licensing deal doesn't make it impossible to release altogether (like Capcom's Dungeons & Dragons PS1, which culminated in a standoff over Mega Man 8 and Resident Evil on the Saturn and not just a different region)
Happened a lot on the PS1.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>9551749
MM is an unfortunate case of a game with really inspired and cleverly implemented ideas that people are right to praise, considering nothing else has done them better, stuck in a something that's otherwise a rushed mess filled with tedium and outright weak design. It was always considered 'decent, but clearly inferior to Ocarina', until later it became 'more appreciated'. People aren't wrong to appreciate what it did right, but it got to a point where people just started ignoring all of its flaws and weaknesses, which really are significant, in favor of looking only at the good parts, which kind of makes sense considering many players with renewed opinions of it would end up basically revisiting the game after 'already knowing what to do' and finding that that can skip a lot of things after the fact due to prior knowledge.

Otherwise the time system is in fact horribly limiting, and heavily restricts how the timed quests can play out (i.e. something like OoT's trading quest just wouldn't work in MM because it has parts where the solution is too open ended for the player to figure out in the timed windows MM gives, while MM's quests are forced to inform you about the time and place of their solution), while most of interesting optional interactions are incredibly out of the way and useless to the actual quests, which are mostly waiting around for shit to happen.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
RE3 has incremental improvements from the dev of RE1.5 and RE2, I don't think you can just drop RE3 into early 1998 and magically have it be the new RE2. RE3 came out in very late 99, CODE: Veronica nipping on its heels and was sandwiched in between Dino Crisis 1 and 2. RE3 holds up better than the aforementioned because it built upon what worked with gameplay, graphics and puzzles in RE1/2.

RE3 is a fairly abrupt side story with most of the foundation being laid down in RE2. Waiting 2+ years to release a well made side story would have gotten a lot of flack in the day for not striking while the iron was hot. You'd have to extend the beginning scenario at the police station to explain how thing went to hell, at which point you're just reheating RE2 but with a way less interesting interesting villains, ie you're making RE1.5 again. The pursuer gimmick works because it disrupts the calmer, reflective moments in survival horror. The nook at the end was a bold story choice, but the decision to move forward from Raccoon City was already made with CV and RE4 (DMC) already in development. Mercenaries won't be as fun due to the reduced gameplay refinement from missing titles not likely to be implemented.

tl;dr gameplay would be marginally better than RE2 as is, but the game would lack the grandiosity and production design that RE2 has.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>9555408
The ribbon cable that the other post mentions happens to most of them in time. There used to be an oven method for reattaching the ribbon cable but you can also solder them all back on if your hands are steady.

Can confirm the VB is oddly assembled and annoying to open/put back together but there's not much inside the unit.

It's a neat system for what it is and aimed to do, only like 4 fun games on it though and you have 1 of them. Warioland, Teleroboxer, and Red Alarm are the other three. I played all 23 or 24 games which came out for it including the JP releases. Better quality games (the complete opposite of the tennis game which was originally included) might have given the system a little more time in the consumer world. There's a flashcart too but the dev only allowed 1 game on it at a time to keep nintendo off their back.

If you love 3D gaming, many pc games can be played in 3D if you have a 3DTV, or nvidia 3D glasses and a 3D monitor. We have fixes for Unreal 4 Engine and many Unity games for anything from DirectX 9 - DirectX 11. It's like a larger and much more powerful 3DS as long as you have at least an RTX card. See Helix Mod for more details.

>>9549597
The truth is that the Enhanced Edition actually kinda sucks. Much like many other remasters, old and new, it messes with the visuals far too much. The colors are washed out, the contrast and saturation aren't right, and it's lacking the chunky pixel goodness. Plus, the last update released doesn't mix well with some systems and may cause the game to be inherently laggy, and there's no fix to it except for rolling back to the previous version, which is only possible on GOG. Play with DOSbox, and if the controls bother you much, there's an easy DOSbox patch that modernizes them similarly to the Enhanced Edition. I'd recommend the Shockolate sourceport, but it's too unstable and the devs are too slow about updating it. I think the CD version lets you have up to 640x480 resolution, which looks really good still.

>>9558138
No. The Gamecube version made big improvements over DC, fixed alot of issues, and added a ton of new content. BB made small improvements and added some extra content to the Gamecube version. Both Gamecube and BB added QOL improvements that I wouldn't want to go back to not having. Most importantly though, BB implemented server-side saving. It meant sacrificing offline play entirely, but in return, cheating was much less rampant, and you no longer had to worry about losing your unequipped items to some jackass freezing your game with an action replay.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>9558330
BB is the best version for online. GCN is the best version for offline play. Compared to DC, GCN doubles the number of dungeuns, adds new character classes, completely overhauls and rebalances the classes for the better, adds an absolute fuckton of new rare weapons to find (the main reason to play the game long-term) and makes their droprates almost reasonable compared to the absurdly low droprates on DC. The Spread Needle is no longer so OP as to completely dominate online play to the point where you won't get a single hit in if a teammate is using one. It fixes the glitch that allowed players to teamkill. It fixes the glitch that allowed players to go through locked doors. You no longer drop your money and equipped weapon when you die, to be ganked by other players. It adds a quick item select like the one in Monster Hunter that makes it MUCH easier to use items and spells that aren't assigned to your main 6 buttons. (On DC, you're stuck with JUST those 6 actions, at least two of which will be your basic attacks. Have fun juggling all those spells if you're a spellcaster) Spells now go up to Lv 30 instead of capping at Lv 15, and only Spellcasters can go above level 20, giving you an actual reason to use a spellcaster. GCN also adds splitscreen multiplayer, which is the best reason to play it. You can play online on private servers, either through a Gamecube with a broadband adapter, or a Wii with a lan adapter, but be warned; you have to take alot of precautions playing any console version online. Any rando in your lobby or your game can potentially freeze your game with a cheat device, causing you to lose all unequipped items on your character. If you're playing online on DC you'll also have to worry about these same cheat device randos overwriting your character data with a Lv 1 NPC named NOL.
Blue Burst is much more secure online; you can play with randos without worry, but there's no offline at all.
Honestly, don't bother with DC.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
Most people know of the top down/isometric action adventure games buried deep within console libraries, but I never see anyone talking about PC games other than LBA and maybe Dink Smallwood.
Of the top of my head, I can only remember two good ones, Al-Qadim: The Genie's Curse and Entomorph: Plague of the Darkfall.
Al-Qadim is pretty straight forward with a nice setting. It has a few classic arabian nights set pieces to get the adventure going, all very simple stuff but it works well to make the game feel bigger than it is. It is a bit stiff, but definetly playable.
Entomorph is a pretty similar to it in structure and gameplay (they both remind me more of Dink Smallwood than Zelda), but has a weirder setting. It is all about insects. The enemies are insects, most of the characters you meet too and as the game goes, you become more and more insect-like. The game has a lot of very memorable moments, I played this a long time ago and I still remember a lot of its subplots. You meet a spider that oversees that fabric of space and time, infiltrate a beehive and learn to mind control insects that are too stupid to resist your mind tricks. The biggest problem is that the game is filled with bugs (ha). I remember getting soflocked at least once.
If you know any other good ones, please share.

posts.name: Anonymous
