>>9551323
>Sega Genesis kept on getting home brew games to this day, but the SNES has not.
The SNES occasionally gets homebrews, but it certainly pales in comparison to the Genesis, without question
>Even though SNES rom hacks are more common than Genesis rom hacks. What is the deal?
Super Mario World sucks up a lot of SNES programmers that might otherwise work on other stuff on the system.
All that aside, the SNES sucks to program for compared to the Genesis, it leans way more on its fancy hardware accelerated shenanigans to do a lot of the things the Genesis can brute force with pure cpu power, aside from the complexity of managing dumb things in the ppu like windowing, color math, etc (the pipeline for which is rather complex if you intend to mix any of these for various effects). The SNES instruction set is also annoying in comparison: only three registers (though memory accesses are 'quicker' than on the 68k) and some types of addressing modes only exist when using one register

>>9554212
Saturn documentation and libraries have been around since the late 90s. Basically Sega of America had a developer portal on their website back in the 90s that led to an FTP server that had all the documentation, libraries, etc. available for developers. But being the 90s it was completley unprotected and anyone who found it could download whatever they wanted. So a couple enthusiasts downloaded that stuff and it's been available ever since for people to use.

Every now and then a disc pops up that has things that weren't available from that site that the community comes together to purchase, but overall the bulk of what was required to do homebrew has been around for well over 2 decades now. So people have had plenty of time to study it.To my knowledge Sony and Nintendo weren't as lax with their dev tools.

There's also the fact that while the Saturn is complicated, you're still writing code in C most of the time, and the CPUs used in it were/are popular in a lot of embedded systems over the years, so they still have support in modern compilers like the latest versions of GCC which produce good and efficient code. So that also ironically makes Saturn development a bit easier than say the SNES.

Yet all the SNES homebrew devs flat out state their biggest hurdle is no decent c compilers or libraries. People have tried, but they still aren't there simply because the SNES CPU was only used in the SNES and Apple IIGS, there's not really any kind of demand for major C compilers to support it. If you want to get anything decent running on the SNES, you have to use assembly. Which combined with all the other odd quirks, limits, and bottlenecks of the system it really isn't something for the faint of heart. It's actually not that uncommon to see a lot of SNES devs start to actively hate the SNES hardware the more they work with it.

Meanwhile the latest versions of GCC still support both the 68k and the SH2 and at least in the case of the SH2 will compile very good and efficient code in most cases.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>9554901
Any CPU can run C code if it has a good enough compiler. The issue with the SNES is that there's literally nothing other than the SNES and Apple IIGS that use it's CPU. So there's literally no point in supporting it for modern C compilers unless your specifically making a compiler for the SNES or Apple IIGS. So there isn't a good enough compiler for it.

Meanwhile the 68000, SH-2, SH-4, MIPS R3000, MIPS R4300, Z80, 6502, ARM60, ARM7, etc. are all very common CPUs and CPU architectures that have been used and in many cases still are used in plenty of other computers, video game systems, and embedded systems over the years. Some are even still in use or their derivatives that are still backwards compatible are in use to this day. So as a result most major C Compilers like GCC all still support those CPUs to this day and keep improving and optimizing what they output to the point where you can get very good code out of them that in some cases is just as good as what you could get from hand tuned assembly.

>6502 C compilers have existed since the late 70s. This CPU was as common as ARM is today. plenty of people "gave a shit".

In that time frame the Genesis homebrew scene has taken off and is has a pretty steady stream of new releases yearly that are pretty notable. Even the Saturn scene is at a more mature spot at this point. Meanwhile the SNES scene is still around the same spot it was years ago with little to nothing to show for it. Kind of like how the Atari Jaguar scene has stagnated over the years for similar reasons.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
Super Solvers Challenge of the Ancient Empires. Wouldn't even qualify as edutainment if the game didn't throw a few paragraphs about history at you after you beat a level. Instead it's mostly a puzzle platformer game that gives decent challenge on normal, and is brutal hard on the advanced difficulty you unlock after beating the game once on normal. Quick and precise movement as well as smart use of your equipment is required to win. Not much education here, but the game is probably the most game-like edutainment game ever to exist. Take out the paragraphs about history, and it might have been a halfway popular shareware title.
Castle of Dr. Brain and Island of Dr. Brain. There's other Dr. Brain games in the series, but they are more of a collection of remotely educational games that you have to do over and over and over again to win. The first two are more like standard graphical adventure games, where you can progress forward after solving the current puzzle, all the way to the end of the game. Much like the other VGA graphical adventure games by Sierra, the entire screen is full of stuff to check out. Jokes, one-liners, and even poems are hidden on the various screens in the games, and only need to be touched or looked at to be revealed. They are a breeze on easy, though possibly challenging for younger players, but on the hardest difficulty the puzzles can be challenging even for adults. Completing puzzles earns hint tokens which can be used to assist or even completely solve puzzles you have problems with. Instead of focusing on just one aspect of knowledge, both games attempt to provide educational material for many fields so you aren't stuck doing math puzzles or spelling problems all game long.
I've seen a lot of edutainment, but these three games are the only ones I've seen worth coming back to and playing again as an adult.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
When talking about Spider-Man video games, it's very common to hear Neversoft's Spider-Man (PS1/N64/DC/PC) and Treyarch's Spider-Man 2 (PS2/NGC/XBOX) being referred to as the 1st installment to properly make you feel like Spider-Man, and it makes sense, the former was the character's debut in 3D, while the latter was the introduction of an open New York for him to go and explore, both of these elements would become a staple for the character, and nowadays it's tough to imagine a Spider-Man video game without an open New York... or in 2D. I do feel his powers work best in 3D, but that doesn't mean there haven't been good 2D efforts in the past.

I wanted to dedicate this thread to those relics of the past that we'll probably never see again for the character, not even in mobile or something along those lines, because at least to me, and contrary to popular belief, it doesn't necessarily take 3D to make a video game where you actually feel like Spider-Man... The Amazing Spider-Man vs. The Kingpin (MD) to me is the 1st real example of the character's powers and moveset being adapted well into a video game, to the point where you do actually feel like him, and it's quite satisfying, especially the webslinging, they nailed it, and this installment is still one of the best in the whole series to me, I recommend it.

Of course there are tons more, some respectable efforts on Nintendo's and SEGA's 8bit consoles and handhelds, especially the GBC's duology, and of course the GBA installments, there are quite a few of those. I believe most will have memories from the SNES and Mega Drive installments though, there were a lot in that generation, some good, some bad, and some more mixed among fans, either way I believe having a thread to discuss there memories, and new discoveries, could be fun, as Spider-Man's 2D career seems finished, especially after Insomniac's titles, so I figured there was no better time to discuss them, as what we have is probably all that there'll be.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>9557860
Well, I suppose I could try kicking discussions off with something that has been on my mind for a while. I talked about The Amazing Spider-Man vs. The Kingpin (MD) in the OP, and I've always wondered about a couple of things regarding it, the 1st is... what's the overall consensus for it? I often see many hold it in high regard, but at the same time I often see it get a lot of harsh criticism, so it's hard to determine wheter it's mostly beloved or simply mixed in its reception. Now, for the 2nd thing I wonder about it, it's regarding its other versions, not so much the 8bit ones, since those, while respectable for the hardware they were made for, can be annoying due to only having a single life and no continues, it doesn't play as well as the original either... no, the main port that strikes my curiosity is the SEGA CD one, I've played it recently after hearing many talk about how it was the definitive version, and while I see how it improves on a few things, it's overall not as fun as the original to me... which version do you consider to be superior, anons?

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>9558360
Elaborating a little on why I prefer the original version over the SEGA CD one, it's due to a lot of things they've added that simply didn't do it for me. Of course, some additions were for the better, especially being able to turn while wall crawling, it's quite smooth. However, pretty much everything else just doesn't really improve the experience in my eyes. I don't dislike the idea of collecting comic books, but when on a timer it doesn't feel ideal... that's what I thought until I realized that the timer resets whenever you put on a password, rendering it useless, which takes away from the immersion, also your comic book collection resets when you put on a password aswell, so you have to collect everything again... they went for a pseudo open New York feel on this one, and the effort is admirable, but for this installments specifically I think it doesn't work much, your main incentive to explore is to find the comic books, which will reset when you put on a password, so you just go for the bosses anyway... I do enjoy this version, don't get me wrong, it plays quite well and does a lot of things right, but I wish they went for a full sequel on the SEGA CD instead.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>9559257
I've been giving the SEGA CD version more thought and, after going for a playthrough on Easy where I do my best to explore New York and find all of the comic books... I have to say that this was quite fun. Only major issue is that the password system doesn't include the comic books you've collected, so every time you pick up from where you left off, your collection resets, though at least the timer resets too. I have to say, this is quite revolutionary for the character now that I think about it, it was the 1st time it had a sort of save system, with the passwords, from what I can remember, since most Spider-Man video games from the time where the kind where you always restart from the beggining and have to complete in a single sitting, and not only that it had a bunch of collectable comic books, a staple for the franchise nowadays, and the closest thing they could've done to an open New York at the time, another staple, and animated cutscenes. I still prefer how the original version plays, it's atmostphere, graphics... pretty much everything, but this is still a respectable and downright revolutionary effort.

posts.name: Anonymous

>>9558519

I really enjoyed Outlaws.

It was though way behind the times - this don't forget was released after Quake, which was full 3D and six months before Dark Forces 2: Jedi Knight which was made by the same studio, again full 3D and taking full advantage of 3D accleration, and all the fancy (for the time) lighting etc that came with it.

From my recollection it was the first FPS I'd played where reloading was a key game mechanic, to the point where the first demo I'd played I genuinely had no idea what to do the first time my revolver and rifles clips ran out of ammunition. I worked it out eventually!

According to Wikipedia it was also the first sniper zoom - though I'm pretty sure Terminator Future Shock or Skynet beat it in that respect (now those games are underrated boundary pushers...).

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>9556134
Chrono Trigger for sure. About as easy as Earthbound but honestly with an even smoother difficulty curve, barely ever need to grind at all as long even if you kind of suck at figuring out the battle system. Story is fantastic - just a great "band of unlikely heroes fight evil" with a well-used time travel mechanic. Fantastic game.

Skies of Arcadia is also very easy. The story is also pretty straightforward, but it's so fucking charming there's so much cool stuff to see and do. Build your own island, recruit ship members, discover a ton of weird shit in a massive airship.

Panzer Dragoon Saga if you can get Saturn Emulation going. Very unique battle system that I'd honestly say is the best one I've ever encountered in a JRPG, makes battles actually really fun an interesting, plus you don't need to grind at all. Unique Moebius-inspired aesthetic and worldbuilding.

The Final Fantasy games take a bit of grinding but aren't too difficult. I like V and IX the best, but if you're looking for a unique story, I hear VI is fantastic (somehow still not gotten around to it myself). V is a bit of a slog I'll admit, maybe save that one for later.

>>9556134
In terms of gameplay, Earthbound is mostly quite similar to Dragon Quest, though the setting and style is very different. If you want something that's set in modern or modern-ish times, instead of medieval fantasy, and which is wacky and weird, there isn't actually that much else, not that I can think of anyway.
The closest ones which come to my mind:
>Fallout (specifically 2)
>Jagged Alliance 1 & 2
>Pokémon series
>Persona series
>Anachronox (maybe, never played this one)
>Sweet Home (horror and weird, but no real levity or wackiness)
As you can see, these all mostly stray quite far from Earthbound, some extremely so.

The exceptions are from the past decade, where there's been an absolute deluge of indie games which proclaim inspiration by Earthbound. The vast, VAST majority of these games are godawful fucking trash which aren't worth anyone's time, least of all yours, and most are some varying degree of exceedingly pretentious bullshit. The most famous is that Undertale game, which differs strongly in setting and even themes, but is weird and wacky, I wasn't that impressed by this game, but a lot of people seem to really love it, so maybe they got something from it which I didn't. The most infamous would be "Yiik", which is like some sort of ghastly blend between Earthbound and Persona 4, if someone were to interpret those games in the most shallow and thoughtless manner imaginable.

>>9556218
Mother 3 drew me in for a while, but then it just started losing me. I wouldn't call it bad, but I feel it just isn't as fun and lighthearted as Earthbound, where the darkness mostly comes in right by the end.
It also feels obnoxiously preachy in some manners.

Didn’t really like Gunman’s Proof - it was kinda cute, but the gameplay was not that fun and it clearly lifted a lot of stuff from ALttP, but made it worse.
Really liked Ihatovo and Live-A-Live, though. Really wish SNES had more unique games like these ones - starting a JRPG and realizing it’s yet another FF/DQ clone in a boring fantasy setting is so disappointing.

OP, you should check out Moon: Remix RPG Adventure. It’s incredibly unique, just make it through the first two hours or so, then the ‘stamina’ system becomes a non-issue and it becomes good. What’s great about this game is that all NPCs have their daily routines which trigger various in-game events, kinda like Majora’s Mask does (Moon did it first, though!) - it makes the world feel alive - finally, NPCs which are more than billboards. It also has great music and non-generic setting/atmosphere.

>>9527987
AoW seems to be written in Delphi, judging from the .dpl files (they're just dlls btw).
The UI uses the Visual Component Library that is based on Win32 API but adds a lot of custom controls. Looks like it was one of the easiest way to build good looking GUIs in Windows at the time.

As for VNs from that time, maybe they used the Windows API with custom engines in C or C++ or even languages like Hot Soup Processor.
Then engines like KiriKiri and Nscripter got popular.

posts.com: I see many mentions of games that hat their own in-game Windows-like interface, yet no mention of Transport Tycoon. Apart from looking and sounding beautiful, it had UI features we take for granted nowadays but that I never saw in a DOS game beforehand. It had tooltips on everything. Its subwindows were active references to the map in that you can build stuff not just on the main map, but any random train screen, message, anything showing a piece of terrain. It was mindblowing at the time.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>9555080
Saturn's sound chip can do both PCM and FM Synth. There's 32 channels and each can either be PCM or a 1OP FM Synth channel. However they can be chained together to make more complex channels. So you can take 4 channels and make 1 4 OP FM Synth channel. You can take all 32 channels and make 1 32 OP FM Synth channel if you wanted. It also has a pretty nice DSP in it for doing echo, reverb, 3D sound, etc.

The Dreamcast kind of takes that chip, removes all the FM Synth features and instead adds ADPCM compression support and increases the channels to 64. Not sure if the DSP was affected or not.

As for the Art and FMV quality, they both look fine on Saturn if you're playing on real hardware or on a CRT. The 2nd game actually has really good quality encoding as it uses the ADX Variant of Cinepak and pushes the bitrate to the absolute limit.

>>9555087
No idea about it's music, but PSP kills the quality of a lot of the voice samples and cuts some out entirely as it tries to cram both 1 and 2 onto 1 UMD. For FMV quality it's maybe on par with Dreamcast or slightly worse.

For FMV and Art resolution it goes PC > Dreamcast >= PSP > Saturn. PC is 578x288, Dreamcast is at half horizontal resolution, PSP I think is slightly lower than PC but with worse compression than Dreamcast. And Saturn is 288x144.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>9555271
The PC versions only work on windows 9x and XP, and their code is a horrible hack job. Trying to reverse engineer and work with that is a nightmare. Dreamcast is slightly less nightmarish. The Saturn versions ironically are the easiest to work with.

As for the FMV encoding, for the first game the subbed encodes are on par with the originals, if not a tad better due to using the PC version as a source. While CRT filters might not help hide cinepak artifacts, actually running on a real CRT with Composite very much can help hide it. This here is a Composite capture from a real Saturn for a Cinepak demo entered in a competition:

https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=JZItu5asIM8

What hurts the first Sakura Wars FMV quality the most is the lower resolution and high frame rate, but even more so the high quality uncompressed audio which sucks up bitrate. For the 2nd game they used ADX audio which allowed them to significantly improve the encode quality..

There's three PC versions of the first two games, a W95/98, CD-ROM 98/ME/2000/XP, and the newer DVD-ROM ones that had 2000/XP recommended but Sega confirmed to run on Vista and will by extension work on 7 and 8 (I feel like at one point Sega had a site specifically mentioning 7 but I can't find it anymore). 3 and 4 had the last two. The 95/98 version was released in 2000 and seems to have had the Saturn FMVs, the 2003 CD-ROM release added more voice lines than Dreamcast.
https://sakura-taisen.com/archives/game/databace/sakura_1.html#WIN_DVD
2-4 had patches and they're all a bit wonky to install, plus for some reason data transfer doesn't work on either 7 or 8 for some combinations of games so it's not perfect but they definitely do work on newer OS than XP.
https://gametaruru.net/game/comparison-sakura4

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:

From what was investigated it was a real mess to get them to work on modern Operating systems, let alone try to debug and reverse engineer them. The games look to be a bit of a mess under the hood as with each port it seems to just add more glue code to make it work on the new platform. The Saturn version is just the original base code so it's a lot easier to figure out what code is doing what, and how to parse and work with the data.

Download RetroArch + Final Burn Neo core and play Neo Geo today, anon.

JAMMA is a set of wiring standards for arcade machines that enabled operators to swap game boards in and out of the machine without needing to rewire it for every new game.
A supergun is the guts of an arcade cabinet mounted inside a small box minus the monitor.
Some superguns have joysticks built into them and some use console-style controllers that plug in.

posts.com: What games should I play? I want to start with some easy ones and then move on to the toughest.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>9550794
Start with Mario, Sonic, Kirby, Donkey Kong Country, Mega Man (X or Classic is fine, but the latter tends to be harder). For Genesis there's Ristar, Dynamite Headdy, Gunstar Heroes, Vectorman, Rocket Knight series, Monster World IV, Popful Mail (technically an RPG but uses platformer controls), and The Terminator (SEGA CD version of course). Finally on TurboGrafx you've got the Bonk games and the Valis series. Some people like Castlevania but I find the early games to be kind of brutal, barring Super Castlevania IV.

For 3D platformers it's down to Mario, Banjo, Sonic, and Crash for the most part. People seem to like Jak, Sly, and Ratchet (more of a TPS/platformer hybrid) but I personally never really played those. Honestly there's so many good platformers on Super Nintendo alone you probably won't get bored with it for ages.

posts.com:

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>9550794
Sonic is probably the best answer. It's easy to get to the end of the levels and beat the game (because it is difficult to die) but as you get better at controlling the character you'll be able to go faster by accessing parts of the levels you wouldn't be able to reach before.

You could also try Super Mario World or Yoshi's Island (both quite easy) and for 3D platformers you could try Banjo-Kazooie, Mario 64, or Spyro.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
A few people recommend playing Sonic at some point, and I'd agree. Sonic 3 is especially short and gives you an "easy mode" by letting you fly as Tails. (Not technically retro, but Sonic Mania also does something similar, and can be a bit more forgiving in places.)
But something to keep in mind: Sonic has a few arcade sensibilities. Sonic 1/2 have no saving, sometimes you need quick reactions to enemy placement, getting all the emeralds is hard and there are multiple routes so it encourages replays. Most big-name platformers in the years following will lean a litle closer to Mario in their structure. So if you try Sonic and find some bits aren't to your liking, don't let it put you off platformers.

The Kirby games are also tailor-made for beginners, while still usually having an enjoyable difficulty curve. Kirby's Dream Land on GB is very easy; and Kirby Super Star has an even easier, shortened remake of it with better graphics as a "first world". Adventure is also

>>9551193
https://www.mariowiki.com/Super_Mario_All-Stars has a list of all of them.

In all of them, the biggest changes are graphics/music, and the ability to save after each world.
Super Mario Bros. 3 gives you a few extra lives to start off, some very minor layout changes, and it lets you run and throw fireballs at the same time.
The Lost Levels has some more extensive changes to make it easier (saves after every level, extra lives on World 9, making access to worlds A-D easier), but it's still the hardest and cheapest game in the collection (and I think the Mario series as a whole).

Haven't played the International version in a while but the Japanese one is really hard, especially during the last couple of worlds. The only difference is the hit system but it's a damn big difference, you basically have one less hitpoint
SMB1 has no continues (yes, yes I know, don't mention it, it doesn't count, that shit is cheating) and you have to learn how the game works and get good to beat it without warps, it takes hours of practice if you've never played it before

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
Kirby games were literally built from the ground up to be easy Platformers for newcomers to get into the genre. If you've never played any games in this style before then this series is the best place to start. Don't listen to anyone suggesting NES games (aside from Kirby) those titles are simpler than later entries but the difficulty is brutal in comparison. Save NES titles for when you feel comfortable enough with the basics that you can handle a challenge.

The games many of you are recommending are excellent, but OP specifically asked for easy games to start with and if they take your suggestions they may get turned off to the genre.

Donkey Kong on whatever system. Game Boy Donkey Kong is a remake and is great.
Mario Bros. with a friend. GBA version is one of the best releases to start with.
Super Mario Bros. 'till completing easy mode.
Super Mario World.
Super Mario 64.

Sonic 1 Master System.
Sonic 2 Genesis.

Metroid.
Metroid II.
Super Metroid.

Don't play kiddy stuff like Kirby. If you need easier than what I've recommended, start with NSMB on the DS, or any New Super Mario on any system.

Also, Hollow Knight is the current best modern platformer, and Super Metroid is the best all-time, but those are harder because they are nonlinear. Start with the linear action challenges like Mario before doing maze platformers (commonly called Metroid 'vanias in honor of also the Castlevania series, which you should also play the first of on the NES).

Finally, and generally: play and make romhacks.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>9553550
>Sonic might be a little bit more of a platformer, but in the sense of actually having to calculate and time jumps to avoid enemies or traps, they're not in the same league as other platformers.

Two things about this:
1. The primary complaint people have with Sonic games is that there are TOO MANY obstacles. Jumping is the only tool that Sonic has to avoid these.
2. Sonic levels have tiered level designs centered around verticality based branching. What this means is that jumps are actually so important to the experience that if you fuck them up you go to a totally different, slower part of the level.

Now let's look at a random section of adventure island: https://youtu.be/v_C-Yql7bHg?t=1216
Totally flat terrain. No branching or variance of the gameplay based on platforming skill. Corridor style level design. Sonic is more of a platformer than Adventure Island and I'd love to have you tell me otherwise. Goddamn you're a retard.

The overall presentation, the storytelling and camerawork etc., has that special touch that just feels 'perfect'.

But it's not perfect. In terms of a game, it's just Zelda. It doesn't try to do too much, and excels at everything it does try. That's what I mean about it being a Nintendo thing, it's not just about bias, it's the way Nintendo products are crafted to have no rough edges.

If we look at the top games of 1998, let me know if I overlook anything important:
>Baldur's Gate
>Grim Fandango
>Metal Gear Solid
>Oddworld
>Panzer Dragoon Saga
>Parasite Eve
>Resident Evil 2
>StarCraft Brood War
>Thief
There's definitely some huge titles in there, all-time great titles. Two things. One, if Ocarina is better than all those games, it's definitely one of the greatest games, but that still doesn't make it THE greatest game.
Two, I deny that it is hands down better than all of those games. Some of them have better gameplay. This is why I've been talking about the presentation so much. I think Ocarina gets credit for being 'magical'. It makes the player feel a greater sense of wonder than pretty much any game because it's a beautifully crafted fairy tale adventure. It has all kinds of charming little details like Link's vocalizations, or simply the way the textures and colours of the objects look.
It deserves a lot of credit for that, but has also been overrated for the same reason.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>9556630
The unite uses the faster character's speed but also magic stat. Strong mages aren't so fast. It also checks for resistance/weakness, but at your disadvantage, i.e. if a lightning+fire spell hits an enemy immune to fire but weak to lightning it'd do 0 damage. Basically, it's very situational to get something out of the unite. What stinks is that it's automatic, so at worst you have to deliberately cast a lower level spell to avoid triggering it. Suikoden runs off 4 magic tiers with a few points in each, depending on the character.

>>9554310
MGS2 was hyped so hard off of MGS1's success that literally no one could be honest about it.
Game Informer reviewer gave it a 10/10 saying it was the greatest game he ever played.

And to this day people still say it's great.
Yet none of them could explain the storyline and all the wackiness in it.

To answer your question, I got the game because MGS1 was like a life changing game to me. I was beyond excited when they announced 2, and the demo only allowed you to play as snake so I was pumped.

Then I bought the game, had to stop playing as my favorite character and play as this wimpy weird guy Raiden..
Had to sit though hour long cut scenes with the characters triple and quadruple crossing each other so you have no clue who is ultimately good or bad..
Then the president sexually assaults you...
Then you run around doing naked cart wheels.
The end.

Seriously, did Kojima go crazy? How could go you from the masterpiece of MGS1, whose story blows away most Hollywood movies.. to a jumble of weirdness. And most of all, they changed Snake and didn't let you play as him.

As you can see I'm still upset 20 years later. And I will continue to be upset forever.

It's pretty easy to explain the wackiness of it. Kojima didn't want to make the game so he purposefully trolled the fans. Then they trick you into thinking you're still Snake until you pull off the mask and you're this faggy blonde twink. Then the whole game is basically MGS1 again until the end when it goes batshit insane in what happens to be one of the most prescient moments in gaming.

It is a great game, exactly because of that sort of thing. The game is fucking with you, and 20 years later its still working.

posts.com:
>>9525483
>Can someone explain to me why source code matters
If you have the source code, the nuts and bolts of how a video game is made, you can potentially create really good modding or editing tools to add on to the game. You can already do with games that don't have publicly available source codes, but with the meat and potatoes of it the possibilities are an order of magnitude greater, including the end-user possibly creating their own game with that code. This has already happened with things like Doom's source code, Quake's source code, etc. On the flipside, sometimes source codes get released (legally or otherwise) and nothing really happens because people don't care enough.
>Why don't we already have it?
Developer, software, and publisher rights. Let's say Ed Boon was the sole owner of the source code of MKII. If it was never released, it's because he didn't want it released. But let's say Ed Boon doesn't own it and the parent company to Netherealm Studios owns the MKII source code. If Ed Boon WANTED the MKII source code out there, he'd have to go through corporate, who could just say no since he doesn't own it. If he did it anyway, he could get sued into the ground.
>Have the games not been downloaded and emulated. Are we not able to see the code then, or hack it? Why not?
All source code is converted into machine code so the computer can read it. That means only the truly adept can reverse engineer a video game, and this has happened more than once.

You didn't ask but I feel like video game studios/publishers should just release source codes far more often than they do. Croteam, the developers of Serious Sam, released the source code for Serious Sam 1's engine for free. But that was in 2017 or so, so literally who the fuck cared anymore besides serious Serious Sam fanboys? Unity, Unreal, Godot, etc. have all taken off. If Croteam had released SE1 back in 2003 after The Secound Encounter came out the FPS landscape might have been different.

>>9529338
Why DO all the characters in MK (visually) have the same normals anyway? In a game with traditional graphics they'd have characters with the same moves and similar outfits to save on labor by editing one character to create the other (draw a Ryu sprite then change the head and colors to make it Ken, many such cases). But in MK they weren't drawing anything, they were just filming actors on a blue screen, so they could have had them all do different moves and it wouldn't have been any more work. posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>9525483
The ROM image contains "low level" machine code that is run directly on the CPU. Programmers write in a highly level code, like C (higher level languages you may have heard of are C#, JavaScript, Python, Java, etc., but old school arcade games never used these as they needed to be more optimised for performance) school, which goes through a "compilation" process to turn it into machine code. The code written by the programmer is the source code, and you can't directly extract this from the compiled machine code. Writing in Assembly is as close to machine code as you can get, but even then, there are comments in the file and descriptive names for variables that are lost in the compilation process. Decompilation projects manually review all the compiled code and try to recreate what they think the source code would have looked like before it was compiled. This can be verified, to a degree, by compiling the manually decompiled code and seeing if it matches the ROM, but all the identifier names and any programmer comments cannot be derived from the ROM image.

The way source code functions as a part of the final end product of a finished game, is that all of the human-readable code has been converted into machine language. Operating instructions for the system to perform mathematical instructions and moving memory around. This is the reason why we can't just "crack" the source code out of a game. The Mario 64 decomp devs actually went through every single instruction and deduced their purposes on a larger scale in a ridiculously difficult and drawn out process using emulators and debuggers.

It is NOT easy. Pic is "source" code. You cannot run this through a converter and spit out legible code.

>>9525706
Simply put, compiling takes source code/instructions written by humans, for humans, and translates/compiles it into something made to be interpreted by a machine.
For example, going from something like the C programming language, to potentially an intermediate representation (like assembly or something else), and ultimately always ends up as machine code.
So you have something high level that makes sense to a human like `print("hello")` boil down to many assembly instructions `mov x y; inc a; ...` down to even more machine instructions expressed as binary (usually rendered to humans as hex) `0x07; 0x6F; 0x32 ...`.

Decompiling is that process in reverse, and worse, it's lossy.
Documentation for the code, written as comments in the human readable source, can't be restored since it gets discarded during compilation (the machine doesn't need these, only humans do). Likewise with function and variable names (usually).
You have to read the opcodes for the machine (from the binary file) and try to deduce what could have produced that sequence of operations.
What function(s) could compile into this specific sequence?
Functions plural because multiple high level concepts can compile down to the same instructions, so even if you find an answer, it may not be the original answer.
Almost like an algebra problem, but worse. y + x = 7, what is x and y? 5 and 2? 4 and 3?

The only thing you can really do is get close approximations, and test them. Did my function compile to the same bytes? Does it "match"?

See also: https://arstechnica.com/gaming/2020/05/beyond-emulation-the-massive-effort-to-reverse-engineer-n64-source-code/

Just as with high level languages, you build up and accrue abstractions over time. I mean that both on a personal and project level. You also don't have a lot of the extra bullshit to deal with like an OS or VMM so you can greatly reduce and simplify what you even need to build and deal with in the first place. You write what you want, how you want to , with the only limits being the target machine itself.
Consider something as simple as loading data from a constant address versus making multiple syscalls to deal with some general purpose file system.

>>9525483
When somebody speaks about "source code", they usually mean code coming from a dev that is cleanly written in a way that other humans with programming knowledge can understand, this makes it much more easy to modify for hacks, ports and what not.

Yes, there are tools to partially or completely see the code from a ROM, the problem is said code looks like an unintelligible mess since it doesn't keep any comments or the given names for variables, functions, etc. Some hackers can work with that mess and slowly figure out what is what by trial and error, the end result would be something very close to the official dev source code, but it takes too much time, guess work and autism, and there's still a chance for inaccuracies, therefore, having the official code from a dev is always more convenient than try to reverse engineer it yourself, unfortunately since it has to come from an official source and may be illegal to share, it's very rare for one to come out, so it's a big deal when one does get released. At least if it's from a game people give a shit about.

So when MK3 was made they decided to add them sort of as a joke.
